150319542.review:
This review is very late but maybe I can change a few minds and maybe give a minuscule of hope to any of the devs. 
tl;dr Please just give the game a chance.

This game is very well done. The graphics and animation are amazing and there is voice acting as well. Stories are fascinating. Each girl has their own story and world to learn about as you clear each Match 3 level. 

Why all the negative reviews then?
Well, the first Mirror game contained a lot of 18+ content. *** scenes, or any nudity for that matter, are nowhere to be seen in the sequel, and naturally people are confused and frustrated as to why they did this. I remember in the very early stages of development, like the first chapter wasn't even done, this game had nsfw stuff (though it was a very long time ago, hopefully, my memory is right). I'm not entirely sure why either but another review said that the new publisher they are with would not allow the game to have 18+ content. They certainly did switch publishers but not sure how true the rest is as I don't have any source. Due to this misunderstanding, they offered refunds through their own site they quickly made which many people found sketchy and people started calling it a scam, which wasn't true at all. 

So who's to blame here?
Well, I think both sides messed up in a way. The developers honestly should have just used a different name. Imagine buying a game called Uno 2 but it turns out it's not a card game it's a FPS. Yes, Mirror 2 is still a match-3 game but they know dam well that's not the main reason people bought the first game.
The gamers buying the game are to blame as well though. This game did not include the 'adult warning' tag that every NSFW game on Steam has so it does have a clear indication that there's no adult content. 

I think people [b]massively[/b] overreacted to this whole thing though. The game is by no means bad. In fact, I think it's actually incredibly good and definitely worth the measly $2 it asks for. But because it doesn't have nsfw content people demand refunds and are review-bombing it. 
First off, if you're willing to spend money on an nsfw game, you almost positively have money to spend and $2 is like nothing to you.
Second off, an initial review bomb is understandable, but why is it [u]still[/u] getting mass negative reviews? The people who left negative reviews in the past several months either don't look at the store page at all or just want to hop on the hate train for funsies.

I was honestly shocked and a bit saddened when I heard the dev company went bankrupt. If this happened to EA or Ubisoft I'd be cheering but a small indie company? Nah. You guys are f***** up. The company 100% could have made more nsfw games after this or hell, they maybe could have made a nsfw patch for this game after they completed it. Now the chances of them making a comeback are slim and would probably take years if they could. 

Feel free to comment if I'm missing vital information or something is incorrect.

146908532.review:
I definitely recommend this game! 

I'm well aware of the controversies surrounding this game, but I mainly care about the quality of the actual game, not the unfortunate circumstances that ultimately led to it's "mostly negative" review score. In my opinion, I believe the largest business mistake they made (that ultimately led to them going bankrupt) was under-pricing the game. I know that's not gonna be a popular take, but the truth is, that game development is expensive and when you consider the high quality, polished end product (even if it's not technically finished) and the fact that they sold over 4 million copies and could only cover a little over a third of their operating costs (according to their bankruptcy statement), the price being charged wasn't high enough. I've paid much more money for lower quality games.........

I've played Mirror 1  and to 200% completion on all the waifu's! Loved that game and highly recommend it as well. While I'll admit I do miss the H content from that game, I still believe that Mirror 2 stands on it's own merits: 

-The match three puzzle game is as addicting and fun as it was in the first game and I do like how they have different icons based on the setting and story you are playing!

-I believe the quality of the stories has improved from the first game (the stories in the first game mostly felt similar to each other, which I guess kinda makes sense when the end goal is the same: have sex with the waifu)

-the graphical quality is wonderful! I also liked how good the animations for some of the bigger flashier moves played out when your opponent used a "signature" move/ability during the "match three" puzzle game!

-Island Waifu dress-up, picture taking, free exploration simulator was a very nice addition; you play the story mode of the main game to learn about the character and then you can go the Mirror 2 Home portion of the game with that character!


I have only two negatives with the game:

-The lack of H content. (but we do live in a world where mods exist, so......)

-That the game will not be officially developed any further.

145011416.review:
Context:
I bought this a long time ago and decided to just let it cook while the devs worked on it. I was surprised to come back and see it  had overwhelmingly negative reviews and that the development company apparently went bankrupt. A lot of people called it a scam and so I figured I'd give it a look after so long and see what the fuss was all about.

This review is from a brief look into just one chapter of the campaign since I wanted to see what made it a "scam".
Review:
This game is  a match-3 battler where you attack, heal, get mana, and overall try to match 3 to win in each match. You can buy upgrades between chapters and overall it's just good fun. The presentation is pretty to look at, the gameplay is solid. The story, while brief, was nice to run through with multiple endings depending on the choices made throughout the game, encouraging replayability.
Overall, yes, you are getting MORE than 2 bucks worth of value out of it.

Edit: It also has a pretty good Slay the Spire inspired challenge mode.

Controversy?
So why all the negative reviews if the game is just 2 bucks and is fun on its own? As far as I can tell there are 2 reasons.
Reason 1: A sequel to an adult game which drops the "adult only" stuff.
This is just a dumb complaint. The game does not have an AO tag. A lot of people are pissy about the 2 dollar stupid-tax they had to pay for not connecting the dots. That's on them. Some people might argue that they could reasonably expect a sequel to an AO game to have AO content, but THE. TAG. ISN'T. THERE. Everything else is a dumb excuse.
Reason 2: Shady company practices
IDK what to think about this. Refunds on a 3rd party site? some claims about giveaways that might have been fake? Claims that the company is collecting and selling player information, which they've outright denied, making it a "he said she said" kind of deal? It does seem like someone handling the company wears a dunce cap on the regular if they've gone bankrupt, and it'd be interesting to hear the story from a developers' point of view. And not just someone on the forum whose source is "trust me bro, i was totally on the dev team"
As it stands, we have the final post from the devs and, if nothing else, they admit to being stupid. Take from that what you will, but my understanding is that MOST of the controversy and hate comes from people wanting an AO game and throwing a collective tantrum when they didn't get it.

Overall:
For 2 bucks, yeah, get it. I'm enjoying it so far and will continue to play some more. I hope the devs land on their feet and continue with a different project under a different name with similar concepts. The game is FUN. The aesthetic is GOOD. For 2 bucks this is a steal!

136212753.review:
If you are a fan of action and adventure games with a touch of fantasy and horror, you should not miss Mirror 2: Project X, the sequel to the successful game Mirror. In this game, you play as a detective who must solve a series of murders linked to a magic mirror that takes you to parallel worlds. The game combines the match-3 genre with the roguelike genre, making each game different and challenging. 

The game also has amazing graphics thanks to the Unreal Engine 4 and immersive music that will draw you into the story. The game has three game modes: the story mode, which has 12 chapters full of mystery and excitement; the challenge mode, which tests you with random levels and enemies; and the home mode, where you can customize the characters with different costumes and accessories that you can get in the DLCs. Mirror 2: Project X is a game that will surprise and hook you from the first moment.

Para empezar, cambiaron totalmente la premisa de la primera entrega y nos tiraron una imagen promocional falsa con el early access. Un pésimo inicio.

Este juego se promociono y se vendió inicialmente (refiriéndome a la primera entrega) como un juego hentai, la jugabilidad trataba de pulir algunos aspectos típicos de juegos de su estilo, añadiendo un sistema de progreso y además habilidades especiales que nos ayudaban a pasar cada fase, esto con la finalidad de avanzar y conseguir todos los finales alternativos posibles.

Esta entrega a nivel de jugabilidad se mantiene y además trata de variar aún más cambiando algunos aspectos en cada escenario, nos brinda además una calidad gráfica superior ya que crearon nuevos modelos y cambiaron el 2D por el 3D bien utilizado. Creo que cambiar la temática, pasando de una fantasía medieval a un plano futurista no fue un error, pero perdió lo más importante que era lo que hizo que la primera entrega se vendiera decentemente y tuviese unas reseñas positivas, el hentai.

Viendo todas las reseñas al respecto el 90% son quejándose por exactamente el mismo punto y no seré la excepción y es que siendo realista, muy poca gente en esta plataforma y con acceso a más títulos del género mucho mejores, jugaría algo así, mataron el único motivo que hacia que la gente esperara una secuela.

Lo jugué muy poco y dudo mucho que lo siga jugando precisamente por el punto anterior, nadie estaba acá por innovación, jugabilidad, sistemas u otros aspectos, estaban acá por el hentai y siendo yo alguien que no disfruta de este género jugando con una mano, creo que es lamentable el retroceso que tuvieron teniendo tantas alternativas y opciones por las cuales optar, tomaron la peor decisión como desarrolladores y equipo creativo, que es perder a su público inicial y apostar por una temática diferente sin motivo alguno.

129728093.review:
This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]  
Mirror 2 is a lewd match 3 game with several different characters, with different attacks and abilities that you will be playing against, in a sort of battle. You’ll have some skills, items and upgrades to unlock with the gold you win after each battle. 

[b]First of all, you should know that the reason the game was massively downvoted was because, unlike the first game, it isn’t an Hentai game as its backers expected and they felt betrayed, BUT it’s still a good game for its price. So it’s sad that the evaluation is overwhelmingly negative.[/b]  

The game offers around 3 hours of short stories in the story mode, all with different characters, set in different worlds and with several different endings. The game also offers a roguelight mode similar to Slay the Spire, with different types of events and where you’ll also get relics and gold to spend in upgrades. This mode has a lot of longevity with lots of upgrades to unlock and three difficulties to choose from.

The graphics have improved from the first game, and now the game is 3D with beautiful scenarios and characters, but some things stayed the same, namely the large and bouncy breasts and the revealing attires, that sometimes interfere with the story, but without any kind of nudity. Some of the sounds also also unnecessarily lewd with a lot of moaning.

The gameplay stayed more or less the same, bury fury was replaced with MP that can be used on items that have a cooldown (that replaced the old power ups that could only be used once). Overall, we could have more skills and items in the story mode, as it seems we have less than in Mirror. Something that bothered be was how we have to start over each time we start a new story, what you unlocked doesn’t stay unlocked, so you end up playing with the same skills and items most of the time 

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 1 Achievement.
[b]How much time:[/b] Around 10 seconds. Game has +3 hours of content.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Easy (story mode) and Hard (Challenge Mode).
[b]Achievements’ Difficulty:[/b] Effortless. Just open the game to get the achievement.

[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
Mirror is a lewd match 3 game that doesn’t deserve to be massively downvoted. It has better graphics than the first game, better gameplay and the stories aren’t disturbingly filled with perversion and taboos.

128411609.review:
After a few hours playing this game, I have a few thoughts.

Another harem plot, basically of all the harem stories you have seen before, you have never seen anything quite like "Gotoubun no Hanayome.” The series has an overall harmony, where this lavishly designed comedy, which sometimes turns into a slightly unrequited romance involving a nerdy guy and five ignorant sisters who hate to study. I forgot to tell you those sisters are quintuplets.

The plot is easy to follow. A guy, Fuutarou Uesugi, nerdy, poor, solitary, gets a job as the tutor of a group of quintuplets who are near to fail the school. This group of girls, Ichika, Nino, Miku, Yotsuba, Itsuki, named in order as they came to this world, hate to study and even more dislike the tutor. After some time, these girls begin showing affection towards their tutor and their surroundings starts to change. The only problem, this kind of plot could be seen absurdness and filled with excessive banality, boring a selected group of anime followers.

But that hardly matters. This group of characters is funny and genuine. In the beginning, you can feel the show as the classical, generic harem where the guy likes and love all the girls. However, in this series, the guy only cares to study and do not see the quintuplets as friends or even more as candidates to have a relationship. I do not think that passed his mind (in the manga is in the same way). The quintuplets have a different personality forcing Fuutarou to take different decisions to deal with each of them. This contrast creates refreshing chemistry between the cast and keeps the whole crazy story spinning, this thing is never boring. As a positive point, I am glad, the adaptation followed the manga and they do not change anything of the plot, so I am hoping to see a second season in the future (it was announced).

The quintuplets have a very different personality; for example, we can observe a clear contrast between Nino and Miku. The latter is shy, dedicate, charming, not social while Nino is very social, extrovert, direct, bossy and probably most of the spectators could end disliking her. The same happens with the other sisters, Ichika, the eldest and the one who tries to keep the group harmony, Yotsuba, filled with excessive energy and who cannot say no as an answer and finally Itsuki, the hard worker and stubborn sister.

On the other hand, the art and sound are fabulous. For me, the art quality is one of the best of the season and I want to praise the creator, the animators because the quintuplets have the same silhouette but with some changes in the hair and the accessories they create different characters. If you pay closer attention to the character design, they will look the same boosting the effect. The sound and voice acting are perfect. The sound appears in the precise moments and it fills the scene. The characters' voice is contrasting and complements the personalities. The OP and ED are good. However, the OP is fantastic because it shows the voice contrast between the quintuplets and has a good rhythm and interesting lyrics.

Mostly, "Gotoubun no Hanayome” is just fun, for Fuutarou to become a better person and starts caring for others outside his family, for the quintuplets whom evolve and begin to experience the love path. Together, they create a cheerful and enjoyable comedy where this group connects between each other and their world expands hilariously.

127814183.review:
This game feels like it's gone through or is currently going through an identity crisis. On the one hand it feels like it wants to be a faithful sequel to mirror on the other it feels like it wants to move away from it. Which ends up creating a product that satisfies no one. Fans of the original feel cheated and lied to(and they 're not wrong) because up until September 30th the developers were completely fine with letting people think it was the true 18+ sequel mirror fans had been waiting for. New players who pick this up will probably be confused as to why this visual novel wastes their time with match three game play to continue the the story.
      So all I can say is this, the developers should probably decide what it is they want to be, do they want to be h game makers tied to the legacy and expectations of the original mirror or do they want to try other things. I'm down for either they just have to actually make that decision commit and be honest with their customers moving forward.
        That being said I would like to congratulate the devs for making a genuinely good looking game. If they had just cut out the match three stuff(also if the had been more honest with their consumers) I could easily recommend this game as one of the best looking visual novels on steam.

126025417.review:
A good tile matching game. It contains multiple different short stories featuring different characters and worlds. Beyond that there is a rogue-like type mode which allows you to adjust the difficulty to your liking and lets you "squeeze some more juice" out of this game, so to speak. The graphics are quite good and the character designs are nice. No outright nudity but characters can still get everything but their underwear blown off. There's also a kinda tacked-on mode where you can walk around as the characters and pose them and such. This mode has Steam Workshop support.

The negative reviews are because coomers got scammed out of a measly couple dollars. I think it was fair on their part to assume this game would be straight up hentai based off the previous game. HOWEVER, I have been following the development of this project since the start and I don't remember seeing the developers explicitly say this game going to be 18+. And when the steam page was revealed I noticed it did not ask for age verification or warn about explicit content. So I didn't expect it to have any. Though I was kind of expecting to see an optional DLC or offsite patch with full nudity pop up at some point but it's whatever. Maybe one day COPIUM

For what it is, it's worth the price. It's a lightly lewd tile match game with a bit of replay-ability. Don't let the negative reviews dissuade you too much. Those people paid for this game assuming it would be porn but it seems the devs did not plan for it to be. A lesson in buying early access games perhaps?

125059848.review:
[b]This is the minorly lewd game I was expecting the first one to be.[/b]

Personally, I don't think character relationships development are shown enough. Actually, they are just minorly shown to you through cutscenes and lines like "It's been a year since then."
All I really need is an excuse to interact with cute anime girls, but then, developing those relationships on screen would literally increase the amount of interactions with cute anime girls, which would make it even better.

I'm not joking. The first character's story, Leah, is literally about trying to befriend her to know what are her intentions, since she seems to be a succubus and could be a threat for the world. But that development in the character's relationship is not shown to the player. Only slightly hinted.
If the devs made the story bits with characters more predominant in the story mode, showing more of that relationship they want so badly to shown developed, guess what? The [b]PLAYER'S[/b] relationship with the characters would also be changed.
Now that I've written this, I can see the problem more clearly. Player and Characters relationship are not developed enough. Insane how we figure stuff out by just writting ideas into a notepad. So yeah, that's what I wished for more. Which is pretty much [b]more interaction with cute anime girls[/b].

The Match-3 Combat is still the same, so it's still solid. And this time there's a rogue-lite mode... which I think requires some balancing. Or maybe I didn't abuse Radiant Gems enough... which does show some unbalancing in its difficulty. Haven't played it enough though, but it's a huge step forward on providing more of the Match-3 Combat.

Also, I kinda wanted to read the in-game stuff, but everything's too small to read. Come on devs, give some extra options for the game, like increased font size and anything else really.

Now, I understand the review bombing the game is receiving.
A lot of people were expecting actual sex mechanics like the previous game, which is understandable. And now the devs are saying that that is not going to happen.
If that wasn't planned, that was the devs fault for not communicating it properly and the review bombing is totally fair. And they are giving refunds for that but, for what I've read, not through Steam's refund system. I would avoid that, that's weird.

[strike]-And also, so far, I would actually not be bothered if there was sex mechanics on the game, different from the first one[/strike]. I think the biggest problem of the first one for me is that it was just too rapey. Everything was just an excuse to forcefully have sex with the girls, or most of them. But, in this game? That's not the case since there's no sex mechanics in the first place. So instead, it's just interacting with cute anime girls wishing  there was actual sex stuff on the game.

But then, can I not recommend the game if it is exactly what I expected the first game to be? A minorly lewd game with cute anime girls. We'll see as this game progress in its Early Access. For now, sure. But bear in mind that it does have problems: like DLCs. Literally too many DLCs. At least I won't bother with that Home mode, where I'm sure people would spend [b]A LOT OF TIME[/b] on, if it had sex mechanics on it.

[b]PS[/b]: Ight, so I decided to get some achievements in the first game for... reasons. And to do so, I had to play through some of the sex scenes, which I fucking hated. Even with my girl Hill, I just can't. So I'm striking the part that I say I would not be bothered about that, because, I think I actually would be. So yeah, keep this Ecchi. Don't need to cross the line.

[b]PS2[/b]: BANKRUPTCY? Well, that's not that surprising. Really unfortunate to be honest. I wonder if there will ever be a game like this that will actually finish development, with no Hentai bullshit, get that shit away from me, thank you. I'm so fine with the Ecchi of this, just don't go too far and I would be vibing.

124404844.review:
yeah i'm not going to lie this one was a little on the south side compared to mirror 1. Then again, this is still early access so my hopes are still high for a proper sequel. As of now, the game feels completely different than mirror 1 did. If you're here looking for a sequel for mirror 1, as of right now, you'll be disappointed. If you're here looking for a wholesome story game that happens to use a matching system, I'd recommend this to you. I, as a proper mirror 1 enjoyer, preordered this game back when there was only one story, and I was kind of disappointed by it. Now that I've come back to the game, and seen all the new stories I have to say the storytelling quality has definitely gone up from the previous releases. A little disappointed in the choices, but I can't really complain, cause mirror 1 did this sometimes too. Though, I feel like if I had a golden pistol that kills anomalies I should have the option to shoot the succubus-fox-girl or if I was possessed by an ancient taoist demon I should have the ability to stay possessed and take over the town or what not. <- I got kinda confused on the OSU-type mechanics though. The dragon story I got pretty confused with, and I was kind of disappointed in the interrogation scene. If this was mirror 1, she would have been kidnapped and strapped to a table with the main character grinding her bones with a circular saw but i understand that's a little much to do in 3d so its not all that important to me. The story was a little short, but I only did one ending, the war ending, so maybe it's longer if you help lynn find her notes. Lani and Rita I have not done yet, but when I do I will update my review.

in conclusion: as of right now this game is not a mirror sequel, however it is a good game by itself. A little lacking in the world building department though, I got confused a little bit on a few stories because the world was not properly described. It would be nice if I had some reference to start on so I had an understanding of the foreshadowing in almost every story. On a scale of 1-10 gotta say its about a 6 or a 7, looking forward to where the developers will take the game next keep up the good work. 

As to the people who negative review this game because there's no nudity, go touch grass, go outside, get some vitamin c honestly. do you really need to have 18+ scenes to enjoy a good story? Plus, it's 2$ and they only sell your personal data to the Chinese government <- which is BASED, by the way.

If you want to discuss anything about the game I will turn comments on so we can communicate about it.

Although the game is kind of good in this price, but misleading words make me hard to suggest it. The title "Mirror" is just too heavy for this game, when the news that the game don't have NSFW content, it lead to majority of users including me cannot recommend the game to the others. And the developer announce don't have NSFW content after 6 months, providing improper way to refund the game does not help.

If the developers would like to focus on 16+ contents, better use title which is not same with previous product, changing the title to something like "Mirrorverse" is a better way, as it have some character which comes from "Mirror", but players can know this game is not same as "Mirror". Also, developers can work with Valve and see any possible way to refund with Steam, there are a similar game "Cyberpunk 2077" also doing this when lots of users think the deliverable content is not what they want.

In my personal opinion, it will be much better to bring the NSFW content to the game, no matter using DLC, fan-disk or mod, this will be the best way to make the reviews become positive, and bring back the reputation of developer and publisher. If the developer really give up to take an action, then "Mirror" will becomes a title that represents poor quality, dissatisfaction, which is really a pity.

Last but not least, I am starting to play the game, which is good for a game in this price range, but I have to say, I buy the game is for the adult content, story will not be the first place. If I want to buy a story-rich game, I would buy other games instead of this, and many players are not interested the genre of this game, which is a bad choice if developer want to make a high quality game, creating a JRPG is much better than match-3 games. Although the story is better than "Mirror", the game never can replace "Mirror" as soul of the game is removed from "Mirror 2", just like what I said in the beginning, the title of the game becomes the burden of the game.

I got excited when i first saw this game because, after completing first Mirror, i thought that this game will have some nice 3D +18 content. So i bought it without any hesitation. Not wanting to play the game on early stages I decided to leave it for later, but then i noticed that it has no +18 tags on Steam. I thought that devs will add it later, or maybe make a +18 DLC. However, after months of waiting, devs announced that the game will be +16. 

The problem is that i only bought this game for hentai. So i feel like i got scammed:
- There was no clear indication that the game will/wont have hentai in it 

- I bought it soon after it went in early access, now, i can't request a refund through Steam, cause it's been months since i bought it

- Devs said they will refund the game, but only on their third-party website that requires you to login throught your Steam account. I'm not willing to share my Steam account credentials to Chinese devs, who have already failed it's audience. Besides, according to other people's reviews, they also request other information for a refund like receipt, Alipay account which i dont have, etc. (Can't confirm this since i didnt log in with my Steam account on their website)

I didnt play the game itself, so cant say anything about it (I kept launcher open for 0.3 hours to be able to write this review). So if you are here because you are interested in a match 3 game - you can try it, due to it's low price i think you wont regret buying this. However, if you, like many thousands of other people who bought this, came here after playing their first Mirror game expecting similar experience - keep your money to yourself, there's nothing to catch here.

123254213.review:
11/18/2022 EDIT: At this point, the developer has been silent and there has been no update for longer than any other point since the game hit Steam.  This goes from a qualified thumbs-down to an unqualified "DO NOT BUY THIS" until the developer comes back and shows they're still working on the game.  Original review follows below:

This game is still in Early Access, quite a while after I initially purchased it.  In that time, it has slowly released new characters, but each character is the same:

[list]
    [*]Slightly branched, but ultimately linear flow chart as you work through levels.
    [*]Match three game play that feels slower and slightly less balanced than the original Mirror.
    [*]Enough risque and suggestive content that you wouldn't play it anywhere you wouldn't play an +18 game, but no +18 content.
    [*]A relatively unengaging story, with colorful characters and adequate Japanese voice acting.
[/list]

I was excited about Mirror 2 because Mirror was a great match-3 game that had great gameplay, great art, great balance and great characters.  It wasn't Shakespeare, but it was a great match-3 game with adult content that was fun to play.

This game originally was supposed to be a Kickstarter project that from the Kickstarter page was the same "Classic combination of love simulator and match-3", but the developers have just come out and said this sequel is a 16+ (not 18+) game, and so you now get the classic combination of a match-3 game with some cheesy 3D beach house mode where you can snap photos of your 3D girls, but only with skimpy clothing on, never anything that would be worse than 16+.

The developer's investment of time and money into home mode and selling DLCs for additional outfits, instead of staying true to Mirror as a sequel that builds on the first game is a frustrating turn of events, and creates at best an adequate match-3 game with an uncomfortable amount of "almost 18+" panty shots and near nipslips content without ever actually having any nudity.  It's annoying cheesecake that I'm not sure who it's for, but that's the content this EA game is shaping into.

If the idea of a match 3 that looks like an 18+ game, but doesn't actually ever cross the line into 18+ sounds like a good idea...wait a year or so for the additional characters and stages to be added, the gameplay to be tuned, and maybe you'll have a pale imitation of Mirror to consider purchasing.  For now, I'd say get Mirror without the 18+ pack and you've got a much better game that's fully baked.  If you want the 18+ content, that also exists for Mirror now, and makes the original Mirror one of the best 18+ games I've ever played.

This?  This game is a game that could have potential if the developers weren't foolish enough to decide that 16+ was the direction to go.

Their decisions around Mirror Home, Mirror Project Y and Z and shutting down the workshop all prove that the developers are out of touch with, and don't care about, their audience.

Maybe this game can save itself over time...the recent reviews for the game are 
[strike]97% "Overwhelmingly Negative (35,155)"
[/strike] 98% "Overwhelmingly Negative (54,848)" as I [strike]write[/strike] update this review...so maybe the developers can see how badly they are handling things.  But I don't have much hope.  I spent a decent number of hours trying to find something worth my purchase price here...but I cannot recommend this game in it's current form.

Note:  I have not spent as many hours in the game as the review suggests, one additional weakness Mirror 2 has over Mirror is a separate launcher to open either the Match-3 game or the Mirror Home world from a separate launcher.  Forget to close the launcher after closing the game and Steam will keep adding hours played while the launcher is open.

123106261.review:
TL:DR Don't believe the salty negative reviews. This Video game equivalent of Halloween III. It's a really good game for what it is. but as a 16+ squeal to an 18+ H-game it has generated a lot of salt. Like I said it's a great game but not the squeal it's audience wanted or expected. Still it is worth playing.

Holy cow how dose a match 3 get this much effort put into it I will never know. Good anime style graphics, great story writing and a bit of suggestive edge to most of it. Easily the best match 3 game you can get. 

And then the completely unexpected addition of an exploitable island was a really neat treat. But like many others who played the original game, I was still wondering. Were is the 18+ content. Hoping it would be implemented soon.

In reality it was never intended to have that content from the start. The devs set out to make a 16+ game with some suggestive content. And on that it dose deliver. Very well.

The problem is the games store page makes it look like it could have 18+ content and while the devs never said it would in any marketing or descriptions it did have the #Nudity and #Sexual Content tags. But so dose Mortal Kombat and a slew of other 16+ games. More to that point since this was a squeal to an 18+ H-game most assumed this would be as well and while the Devs never said it would have 18+ content they also epic failed by not saying it wouldn't have 18+ content.

This has led many who purchased the game (many fans of the previous game I surmise.) to be quite salty and retaliatory in response. However the devs have tried to apologist as best they could and offered to refund any copies purchased prior to Sep 29 2022. They have also removed the #Nudity and #sexual Content tags from the game the same day.

Personalty I would I have liked it to have 18+ Content. But it not being there doesn't take away from the game. And should the devs been more upfront about it's lack of content? Definitely!  But they did do something to try and make things rite. maybe only because they got caught. Maybe not. But that's more then EA would have done.

Aunque el funcionario dio una ruta de reembolso, pero al igual que el perro salvaje se niega absolutamente a escupir la carne que ha tragado, la mera necesidad de completar la información personal para el reembolso es muy sospechosa, ¿el funcionario espera que volvamos a creer en un mentiroso? Por lo tanto, le recomiendo que use PayPal reembolso, porque ese no parece requerir completar los detalles.

Les commentaires suivants que j’écrirai dans quatre des langues les plus parlées dans le monde:
Les fabricants de jeux sont des menteurs sans fond, comme des profiteurs spéculatifs. Ils ont clairement indiqué au départ qu’il s’agissait d’une suite, et plutôt vaguement la question de « y a-t-il un contenu restrictif », que je crois que la plupart des gens ont acheté à cause de cela, car sans contenu restrictif, alors le jeu est un divertissement vulgaire + script industriel (pas d’histoire de nouveauté et de clichés fanés). Il y a beaucoup d’excellents romans visuels dans ce monde, et il y a aussi beaucoup de nouvelles façons de jouer et de s’amuser, et il est fortement recommandé de ne pas gaspiller votre précieuse vie dans ce jeu gimmick qui est en dehors du jade doré et perd dedans.
Bien que le fonctionnaire ait donné un itinéraire de remboursement, mais tout comme le chien sauvage refuse absolument de cracher la viande qu’il a avalée, le simple besoin de remplir des informations personnelles pour le remboursement est très suspect, le fonctionnaire s’attend-il à ce que nous croyions à nouveau en un menteur? Je vous recommande donc d’utiliser PayPal remboursement, car celui-ci ne semble pas nécessiter de remplir les détails.

120364238.review:
(Remember this game is still in EA, so a lot of things - and I hope they do - could change).

The original mirror was a masterpiece. Whilst it did have its fair share of problems, in retrospect it was definitely one of the more defining H games out there.

The most defining difference in this game is the use of fully animated 3D graphics. Whilst its not AAA levels of detail, it is still of an excellent quality. This change helps convey the emotions of the characters much better than just text like in the original. 

The voice acting in this game is a considerable step up from the original. Whilst there was some very talented VAs in the previous game, some was quite amateurish, making the quality inconsistent at places. The VA for the characters so far do a pretty good job (except Norman, which is unfortunately quite bad). The dialogue doesn't feel natural at times but is not glaringly so. The translation for English and Chinese feels much smoother than the previous game.

In terms of the story quality itself, having a story tree with various endings is an excellent design approach. The option to explore multiple endings that aren't just limited to pain and pleasure really opens up the depth to the story. For the character's so far, Leah's is pretty good, Lani's was a little abstract, but still solid.

The final character is one of my - and I'm sure most people's - most anticipated character. Cai Yun. She featured one of the best story in the previous game, and I was very hyped to see it's continuation. Unfortunately, there seems to be a time skip, and it didn't feel like a continuation of her story, more of just a different variation. The story itself was pretty solid, although I do think it pales in comparison to the story of Mirror 1. Since this was the newest character, her story tree was barely developed, and the main branch felt quite short and unfulfilling. However, I'm sure this would be expanded upon in the future.

Aside from the main story, you can read pieces of lore as a drop from each level. The contents are very interesting, but it felt pretty bland reading it purely as text. Whilst I appreciate it might not be possible to accompany all lore pieces with a CG or cut-scenes, some different ways of presenting these lore pieces would make it much more engaging.

Next, the biggest problem with this game. It will not contain any H scenes. This is more than just me needing to go to horny jail, but as weird as it sounds, the IDENTITY of Mirror was very much thanks to the H scenes. Mirror 1 is a masterpiece because it was a H game where everything surrounding it was polished to perfection, so what is Mirror 2? Not the story nor the gameplay has that much an appeal to a new player, and if this was not a Mirror sequel, I would surely not be recommending this. As unfortunate as it might be, the developers more or less confirmed that this game will not have any H scenes. Due to this reason, I will say that as a Mirror 1 player, get this game. But if you haven't played Mirror 1, this game will hold no charm to you.

The music in this game didn't leave that much of an impression on me. I won't present this as a bad point since I didn't find them unenjoyable at all, but considering some of the legendary tracks in the prequel, it was a small yet bitter shame.

Finally I will talk about the gameplay. It is more or less similar to Mirror 1, with a change on the rage mechanic. Progression is only present in the same story (account progression do not carry over between stories). I am personally not a fan of this, but it is not too much of a bother. The gameplay is different, I can't say there are any visible upgrades from the prequel, but there is two moderate downgrades. 

Firstly, the animation of the gems being cancelled out felt very glass-like and light. It doesn't really bring the same level of satisfaction and epicness as when you get a massive combo as before. This is not the only reason it feels unsatisfying to play. Since this is no longer a H game, all clothing tear are completely removed. This was also one of the iconic identities of the previous game, and having this gone makes the gameplay feel empty. 

Secondly, connecting 3 gems has no effects. It was one of my favourite things to do in the previous game, and I was fully expecting a unique animation (even more, a unique animation for each character would be amazing!), but unfortunately, nothing happens. Shattering the gems themselves also didn't feel like you are bringing a powerful explosion, more like breaking a glass panel (see previous point).

I do feel like the need to mention, one aspect that some may consider an upgrade is that during the fight, the enemy's signature ability gets a unique cut-scene animation. I am indifferent about this mainly due to the fact that it feels exactly like a cut-scene - it doesn't feel like it flows with the fight, but rather forcibly sewn onto it. It's not obnoxious enough to ruin the flow of gameplay, just that it doesn't feel impressive.

In conclusion, this game does not live up to the prequel's name, and even with all the changes suggested, it would only elevate it's status from "Original Mirror players should also try this" to "This is pretty fun for original Mirror players." I still don't see its appeal as an independent game. In attempting to change too much from the original, the game lost its core identity, and it is clear that we are far past the point of bringing the energy of the original game back. With a reluctant heart I will still recommend this game from an objective point of view, but personally I still feel disappointed due to how differently the game could have turned out.

Don't read the negative reviews. Most of them are bashing the developers for removing R-18 content due to their country laws in relation to adult content and its complete ban. However, I believe this game has a lot more than that going for it.

Mirror 2 is match-3 type of game where you are greeted with awesome-looking and detailed mmd models, great visuals, fantastic animations, decent voice acting and solid gameplay. To top it off, the game has multiple endings FOR EACH STORYLINE you play! This game has improved in every single department compared to its predecessor and it is an eye candy that I can't get enough of. What's more, at this price point it is AN ABSOLUTE STEAL! I'd be willing to pay a lot more for this knowing the amount of detail and effort put into it. I liked this game quite a lot more than HuniePop 2 that released earlier this year despite the fact that it does not feature any R-18 content. Yes, the themes are somewhat suggestive but they don't go overboard which makes it easy to recommend to those who consciously avoid or feel uncomfortable playing R-18 games. 

Update: there is 'home' where you can control the characters, explore the location and find new poses and points of interest. So, it's basically two games in one which is even more INSANE. However, 'home' right now doesn't have much content and the characters and their postures are somewhat limited in how you can customize them. Feel free to exlore at any time, no R-18 content as of now.

Note for fellow Lowspec Laptop / PC Gamers like me: the game is somewhat graphically intense featuring really detailed models and some fancy visual effects so keep in mind that this won't run smoothly on any random potato PC. You need to at least have 2 cores / 4 threads clocked reasonably ( at least slightly above 2Ghz ) and a capable graphics cards ( at least Vega 3 in double channel / any discrete graphics cards above GT730 GDDR5 variant ). 
My specs: Athlon Gold 3150U 2 cores (4 threads) + Vega 3 (in double channel) = 1080P lowest -> 15-25 fps, 720p low -> 30-40 fps. I didn't exactly see the fps counter, but I'm pretty sure the numbers are close to real results. Is it playable? Yes, but you have to compromise some visual fidelity for that. Just a friendly warning and something to keep in mind for those who play on lowspec machines like mine :)

119071277.review:
As a visual novel, the story of Mirror 2 is good, and the graphics/voices are of great qualities. Three different stories seem to be written by different authors/directors, they have different styles so that Mirror 2 offers a very diversified and immersive experience. The stories themselves are interesting, although I think the pace of some important parts are too quick (for example, the event before Caiyun's last battle) - adding more narratives or dialogues might help.

The gameplay part is also excellent. I never expected a minigame can be so interesting and strategic. The gameplay is basically a turn-based 3-elimination game, with a JRPG-like combat system. The GFX and SFX are also of top qualities.

However, the challenge mode still needs great improvement. First, the balance of items is too broken: some items are so good and they almost immediately ensures victory. Second, player is stronger in level 2, but the enemies are not - it will make level 2 much less challenging. Third, although we choose one character for the challenge mode, but we cannot see any related graphics and hear any voices about the chosen main character through the gameplay. The only difference are different HPs and skills. Please add sounds or animations for the movements of different main characters!

Before I get to the part about learning Japanese, though, let me first comment on the cultural implications of hentai. After the second world war, which Japan lost after the nuclear bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the entire country underwent a period of self-reflection and soul-searching. They wanted to understand how events led to the rest of the world responding with such devastating atomic attacks. This led to a strong antipathy towards war-mongering and international aggression. You may have heard about how the Japanese constitution doesn't allow the country to have an active military. Same idea. A lot of post-war Japanese culture is a reflection of such attitudes. For example, the Godzilla movies are not just about giant monsters fighting each other. They're about the horrors of unbridled atomic technology (Godzilla's always depicted as being powered by or healed by nuclear power), and how such a terrifying force can never be allowed to be unleashed on humanity again. On a similar note, Japanese animation enjoyed a resurgence of popularity after the war, due to the populace choosing to turn towards the comforting images of their youth. Japanese kids, much like kids in our country, like to watch cartoons. As a result, psychologically speaking, cartoons represent a reminder of a simpler and more innocent age. This upsurge in popularity resulted in animated images pervading almost all of Japanese culture: from movies, to television, to advertising, to music videos, and so on and so forth. And because animated images were so widely accepted throughout Japan, they were used for almost every type of source material, or to tell any type of story. Animation was no longer the sole domain of children. You got animated movies that told very mature stories, like Ghost in the Machine or Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind. Sometimes you get stories that involve very mature topics, like war, or murder, or rape, or torture. The Japanese have generally become quite accustomed seeing depictions of such things in their animations. So yeah, that's why I was watching this movie. It's an epic tale about a space crew exploring a distant planet (the crew's all female, because Japan's very into gender equality), and they run into a hostile alien, with a bunch of tentacles... and... well... I don't want to spoil the story for you, but let's just say the crew eventually figure out how to get along with the alien. It's a story about bridging cultural gaps and finding common ground. Seriously, it's worth watching. Ok, next, you remember how I talked about knowing Japanese words and phrases now? It's because these movies are subtitled in English, so I can learn Japanese while watching them. I mean, I know words like yamete, and iie, and iigu, and lots of others. Much better than just knowing konichiwa, isn't it? I mean, I'm developing such an interest in hentai that I might just major in Japanese when I'm in college. Who knows, I might be the one writing the subtitles in the future. Oh, and one last thing, you should know that hentai's considered pretty mainstream in Japan now, and it's also quite common in the western world too now. Everyone's watching it. I mean, if I don't watch it, I'll be seen as some sort of freak at school. You don't want your son to be some kind of pariah because he doesn't watch hentai, do you?

118369002.review:
[h1]Mirror, the SFW version[/h1]

Let's get this out of the way - there are not NSFW scenes in this game. It is possible that the devs may add them at a later date, but  they may also not for reasons I will explain.

Like the first game, Mirror 2 consists of you passing through the shards of a mirror into disjointed, parallel worlds where various drama is taking place, which you solve by playing bejeweled. This game puts a much bigger emphasis on story than its predecessor, which is likely why the devs did not add the H-scenes. While that is slightly disappointing the truth is that erotic content would just get in the way, and honestly the game is better for it. 

The greater emphasis on story also means that Mirror 2 takes a different graphical approach than Mirror. Where the first one had static yet detailed 2-dimensonal drawings, Mirror 2 is almost entirely in 3D, akin to Honkai Impact or RWBY. Despite this, the game keeps the same aesthetic from the first game, and when combined with the environments it looks beautiful. Still, some people have been turned off by it, so make of it what you will.

Mirror was known for having a variety of characters from various worlds, and this game is no different. Though at the time of this writing there are only three stories, that is enough to say that we will be seeing new faces in addition to old, all of which I quite like so far. It's just a shame we don't get to see "more" of them. 

The game is 2 USD, and for that price you might as well check it out if it seems even slightly interesting to you.

118108314.review:
Actually great. Would make a great FULL game with the characters, stories, music, and overall graphics. Sadly it is barred behind a set up of candy crush. If developers realize the potential this holds and maybe increase price and budget, we could have a game on par with many upcoming anime games. Either way it still is enjoyable for a story, similar to an interactive show where your input matters. A system of branches allow you to go back and finish all the different endings and possibilities. Rewards are art and items for you progress through the Candy Crush like minigame. Much like the previous game same mechanics with minor alterations. The story is heavily entertaining, too me at least, and I find all the characters having a personality you can either relate to or connect/empathize. So far have only finished two but have loved it. If you came for R-18+ because of previous game, not here. Maybe once it comes out of early access they might add it, but so far for a cheap price hella nice. There is also a challenge mode that is in the main game that I have yet to try, but if it is worth mentioning I will come back and edit this review to share a quick summary. I did just mention a main game, and that is because there is a second "game" which is a sort of photo taking island. You can change outfits, do poses, go in or near certain objects. Personally, I don't really care to much for it but others might. There are mods and the capability for mods in this second "game" if one wishes for some custom-custom experiences. For the DLCS, they are cheap and support the devs, which does not hurt. I got them all and they seem not necessary but a nice cheap add on.

TLDR: Good game with great graphics, writing, cinematic, characters, and music. Some slight ecchi in some certain areas. Multiple game modes/games.
Horny- Wait for full release to see if added. Or try it out in the first bit and refund... its like 2 bucks and the content is worth imo. 
Not Horny- Get it and enjoy the few stories added so far, obviously not finished so there is much more to come. Might have even been some early hints in the Leah's story of what to expect ;).

Edit: Challenge mode is pretty neat. Its a simple, what im assuming endless, branch-like board game set up like you would find in a mobile gacha game. You have 1-3 options of a path to go to that offer different scenarios. A heal, maybe an item, event, and of course the funny candy crush. Is it top tier game play? Preference really, but if you love the game enough and cannot wait for more story its perfect for wasting away time. From the short bit I played, I did not notice any immediate rewards other than items and passives/skills for further challenge progression. There must be something a player earns from playing though, whether its a cosmetic for the little house "game" or items for the main stories idk. Maybe later this is how you unlock scenes if you know what I mean ;). Again though, no one knows if they will ever add those so don't cope too hard. Just try it yourself if you want more info on it really.

Francamente no sé como este juego cuesta tan poco. Sí, es un juego de puzles de reventar tres o más de lo mismo para ganar, pero tiene historia, personajes, animaciones, doblaje al japones, y todo tiene un nivel de calidad altísimo. Usa unreal engine 4, y su apartado artístico es cel-shading… se parece a guilty gear Xrd.

El juego pues va de eso de hacer estos puzles, ver las cinemáticas y los eventos point and click, pero… ya no hay contenido explicito, y me parece una decisión buena, con tanta calidad ¿para qué? y sí, sé que el mirror anterior sí tiene este contenido y yo lo aplaudí, más que nada porque en ese juego (y otros tantos) eso suma y hace un buen complemento.

Y la historia… son varias y no tienen nada que ver una con la otra, en una estas en un laboratorio investigando a una súcubo, y en otra eres un mercenario acompañando a una chica gato, después eres un chino ayudando a una jiang shi, ninguna relación entre ellas, salvo la calidad de los diseños, animación y demás cosas que ya mencioné.

De momento las cosas malas se reducen a tres; no tiene nube, si lo instalas en otro equipo toca iniciar de cero, no es tan jodido, (y puede ser porque es un early access) encuentro el juego divertido y hasta relajante, otra es que el juego ya no es tan compatible con ordenadores de gama baja, usa unreal engine 4, de nuevo lo paso por su calidad, y el ultimo, lo que más me preocupa, tiene un launcher propio, allí hay noticias de parches, actualizaciones, dlc´s, está bien, pero me entra la vibra conspiratoria al ser éste un juego chino, aunque igual el gobierno Chino ya debe saber quién soy desde hace rato.

De momento se mantiene en early access y por ahora hay tres historias con cinco monitas, puede que agreguen más, y eso espero, en cuanto a la ausencia de contenido explicito, lo encuentro bien, francamente no creo que sume mucho a la experiencia. Me gusta y si tienes poco dinero y quieres un juego simple que entretenga pues adelante.

117617759.review:
Watching the trailer for this game on the store page, I realize there's pretty much none of that content in the game as of yet.  It's currently just two characters (was just one character when I bought it) and they're adding to it as time goes by.   The base game is very cheap, and the DLC they're currently selling is not needed to enjoy the game.  You might want to buy the DLC anyway as a means to support the developers who are still working on this game though.

So for those who don't know (maybe you didn't play the original game?) this is basically a story with some match-3 battle modes in it.  If you played the first game you know what to expect, but so far the content is much tamer as far as sex is concerned (I'm OK with that.)  There's still pretty much the same system as the first game: a physical attack, a magic attack, a heal for yourself, and some matches increase your power to allow you to use special tools to do additional damage or heals. 

This time the story branches out due to choices you make as you play and the challenges may be different depending on those choices.  Of course you'll want to go back and experience all branches of the story, and it doesn't take long to go back through and play another game till you can make the other choice you didn't take. The animation and voice acting is pretty good, and in some cases you have a minute or two of watching the cutscene before you can even play.  They ARE skippable if all you want is to match some symbols and get points but you should probably watch them at least once so you have an idea of what's going on.

So far, the challenge is pretty light.  Maybe it'll get more difficult later, but from my experience so far, it's been fairly easy, though there IS a challenge mode now where you take on some random enemies and that IS harder.  If all you care is to find out more about the story, then the difficulty probably suits you fine.  If you're looking for a serious challenge or lots of fun then maybe you will want to wait for the game's full release (at which time I'll revisit this review and edit it if I remember). 

The graphics are actually pretty good, the story could be a bit more fleshed out but it's somewhat interesting.  I think some of the writing suffers from the developers having to think of how to fit in another combat session in some of the story bits.  Maybe they can rework the story a bit later?

Overall, I'd say that for $2 (or less on sale) it's worth that much at least. I'm still looking forward to the rest of the game being finished, but I'm glad they're not trying to release it all at once and instead are just adding more levels to it as they go along.   If the idea of buying an unfinished game bothers you, then wait.  Otherwise, the price isn't so much that you're being ripped off.  There's at least $2 worth of content in it now and it'll only get better as they add to it.

117590818.review:
[h1]Show Bobs And Vegana[/h1]

[b]On a serious note I expected this whole game to be like that, because the first game was all about shagging girls. This game isn't like the first one.... Not at all. Am I dissapointed? Nope![/b]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3ZZxoaI_gTc
What I meant with this? There are no "Doki Doki" scenes and you are not doing "Doki Doki" with the girls. The gameplay is still the same tho. It is a Bejeweled clone: You match +3 Gems together and activate their effects. You can either heal yourself, attack (magic/melee) or regenerate mana (to use special abilities). When you finish a level you get money, which you can use to buy stronger abilities or level up your character! 

Like I said... Still the same as the old one in these regards!

What really blew me away tho was the fact that the storytelling has become so much better. The story for each girl feels shorter, but there are more than only 2 endings for each (unlike the first one). Replayability is given! Each story arcs are as heartbreaking and enjoyable as you might know from the first game. Rollercoaster of emotions! The graphics (3DG) is also really impressive. Even the expressions are on point.

Another reason to get into this might be the "Home" mode. It is a small island you can walk around with your favourite girl. Dress her as you like and do photos. The photo mode is impressive and has lots of options. You can even make your own poses. There is even mod support to add custom 3D models so don't forget to check out the Workshop!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2825774065
[code]All in all this game is really nice and totally worth the price. It is still not completed and far from it. They add things with regular updates, but it will take some time to get to the final release. So far there are only 3 girls. There also might be a R18+ Patch someday, but who knows.... I can assure that the game is already worth the asked price![/code]

All I can say is that if this is a Visual Novel, I have a very wrong concept of what a visual novel is (which is probably the case, to be honest). To me this should be classified as a puzzle game with a perverted twist, since that's what it is. I'm not going to refund a 50c game that I've played for an hour because that's a dick move, but I'm probably never touching this game again. And to be fair the puzzle game is kinda fun. There's a reason bejewed is cloned so much. I already had my 50c's worth.

- Fun puzzle game. Very similar to HuniePop
- Nice end game artwork
- For under $2, this game is a steal

Cons:
- Super short. Can finish a character in under an hour if you're using the convenient flowchart
- Lacking of any character development. Character development is done with these readable files you can obtain after a puzzle fight
- Lacking of characters. The challenge mode has more characters, but they're more like images rather than a 3D model.
- English localization could use some work. Some of the texts aren't in English for some of the items I saw in the obtainable files after a puzzle fight. 

 But for under $2, I'm not too worried about these cons over the pros. 

Cant wait to see the final product after the devs are complete!

It's... debatable. In certain areas, it's great, but in others, it's a nose-dive.

Let me just get one thing straight. As of April 28th, the game is still in Early Access, and still will be for months, maybe even the next year, and it [b] does not have any H-Content. [/b] This means exactly what you think; no birds and the bees. The closest you get is "spending time" with the girls. Which is just screwing about with them, but not actually, well, screwing them.

That alone will probably turn you away, and I completely understand, as it's doing the same with me. I bought Mirror 1 because of very obvious reasons, and it was an enjoyable match-3 puzzle game with RPG elements. While this game is basically the same as the first, but with 3D elements, it doesn't have the 'stuff' that you're there for.

Now, don't get me wrong, the game itself is pretty well made, other than the obvious bugs and glitches and weird stuttering (along with the heavy usage of CPU and GPU, which is a tad worrying), but as it's in Early Access, you have to look past that. The game has full on cutscenes and choices with different endings, and it seems well-made for what it is, especially for the price.

All in all, if you're looking for a very simple, and (currently) barebones puzzle game, I'd skip, as the devs are extremely untrustworthy, but for anyone like me clearly wanting the H-Content, you're sh*t outta luck. go find something else.

EDIT: [strike]After talking with someone in the comments of this review, it's come to my attention that the game's H-Content does actually exist, and might come in the future. Most likely at it's full release, but until then, I'm keeping this review negative as the H-Content is still the big factor in why I don't recommend it for people like myself.[/strike]

EDIT 2: so that was a f*cking lie. screw these devs. do not buy this game even if it's 2 bucks. it's not even worth that. especially considering we've been lied to lol.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

112230464.review:
I chuckled initially at the "This is a story-driven game" given the games in the series. However the bare bones that is currently the story shows potential greatness. If they continue with the themes of integration to foreign societies, compassion and courage to understand someone different than oneself, for one to change one's ways and being strong enough to stand-up and take action to do what one views as right; it truly will be a fun experience to go along with the fun match-3 gameplay. I am glad Lost Ark went down for maintenance so that I could play this.

My only concern is how 2 of the four endings involve having the MC's mind becoming Leah's plaything. [spoiler] "Ending the run early" and taking action against the Board seems to be the only way to avoid becoming a puppet. Though I'd argue every ending makes you a puppet to Leah in a regard.[/spoiler] That type of manipulation is exceedingly worrisome to me and I would like to see it minimized in the future. I understand manipulation of the senses is kind of Leah's thing being a [spoiler] succubus [/spoiler] and that there is a kink for that type of situation; I am just not the target demographic for such things and while I don't mind it being represented for those who are, I would like it to not overpower the story-telling as a whole as well as with the sub-stories with each of the characters.

I hope those of you who read this enjoy the game and play it when it is fully released. I know I'll be looking forward to it.

To the developer(s): Please keep up the good work on this game. You've done well thus far.

Lani Content Update Edit:

I've recently played through the new story content featuring Lani and Norman. A good post-apocalyptic setting with a wholesome adventure with a cute pairing. Again the story here is a bit light, very much still a skeleton but it is a healthy one at that. This time the story is about making a choice that is better in the long run versus being selfish in the interm. The addition of artwork specific to endings is a great idea. 

Not much else to say that I haven't already said. Lani is exceedingly cute and the team making this game is continuing to do an excellent job. More power to them. :)

111943910.review:
Mirror 2: Project X is a tile matcher game, where you have to take on supernatural beings and protect man kind.

This game looks pretty good. The character models, area and the whole thing in general looks pretty nice, well except when hair or the arm go into each other. The gameplay seems same as other tile matcher game, but there are plus elements which make the whole software more interesting. The sound design is all right. The controls easy enough for this game.  The challenge mode is actually pretty difficult and adds variety to the game.

I know this is an Early Access game, however so far, it's really short. You get only one being's campaign, which have multiple endings, but the story itself is not a big thing to be honest. The developers already announced new character and story for the game, but I think I need to mention it anyway. You can play through the story in 30 minutes, which is really short. If you looking for nudity, this title doesn't hold that.

All in all, Mirror 2: Project X is decent title for some casual tile match gameplay, and for it's price, it definitely gives enough to recommend. You can give it a shot, even for the full price.
